awd_titl_txt: Equitable and Efficient Resource Allocation using Stochastic Fractional Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
This award contributes to the advancement of national health, prosperity, and welfare by studying the equitable distribution of limited resources among participating entities. In this setting, equity is measured by considering the ratio of each entity's need to the supply it receives. These problems, known as fractional programs, arise in a number of settings, and are difficult to solve because the objective functions are highly non-convex.  This project will address the efficient solution of stochastic fractional programs.  The methodology will be applied to improve equity in liver transplantation, where a large dataset of supply and demand data are available, and to stochastic Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA), a widely used method for evaluating relative productivity of decision making units. The project will support graduate and undergraduate education and provide opportunities for students to develop operational methods to tackle societally important problems. 

This research project will develop solution methods for novel stochastic fractional programs (SFP). These problems are challenging to solve, and obtaining an optimal or near optimal solution requires development of efficient algorithms. SFP problems have limited structure when compared to a general nonlinear optimization model. The research will exploit this structure in algorithm development and will investigate technique to generate the scenarios to approximate the original model.  Computationally efficient algorithms will be developed to solve the approximated problem for the linear, convex-concave, and convex-convex cases. Building on this, distributionaly robust generalizations will be used to facilitate sensitivity analysis, and a chance constraint model will be explored. The performance of the developed methods will be compared against general purpose nonlinear, and global optimization solvers NITRO and BARON.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on models arising in the situation where equity is measured by considering the ratio of an entity's demand to the supply it receives. The research investigated development of computationally efficient algorithms to solve approximated problems for the linear, convex-concave, and convex-convex cases in context where the models parameters are random and the knowledge on their probability distribution is ambiguous. As an application the research considered allocation of ventilators during pandemic and allocation of donor livers in the national transplant system. Additionally, stylized equitable resource allocation and production efficiency models were studied. 

Two algorithmic approaches to study distributionally robust fractional linear and nonlinear models were developed within a common framework. These algorithms were ensured to have guarantees with a significant improvement in the convergence rate. Moreover, motivated from the liver allocation model, a novel framework for allocating resources to a large number of parallel queues was developed. This framework was analyzed, and algorithms were developed to solve the resulting problems to optimality. Novel optimization models, motivated from Covid-19 pandemic, for equitable allocation and sharing of critical resources (ventilators) were also developed.

Several novel accomplishments are reported. The developed algorithms solved linear and nonlinear fractional optimization problems which were not solvable using the state-of-the-art methods available prior to the start of this research. These algorithms were developed in a common framework that allowed their generalization to situations were the data distribution is partially known. Convergence of Sample Average Approximation of the models involving continuous distributions was also established. It was also found that solving the problems involving distributional ambiguity can be solved with moderate additional (about two times) computational time.

We found that compromising by just a few percent on efficiency has a very significant impact on equity improvement when allocating limited resources. Using real data, we also found that sharing of critical resources in the context of ventilators needed during Covid-19 could have saved nearly 500 lives over the first three months of pandemic, should ventilators have remained in short supply. The key fact leading to such a finding is that the demand for ventilators peaked at different times, and one could take advantage of these staggered peaks in demand in a resource allocation optimization model while allowing for sharing managed by a central controller. The research article based on this paper was awarded the best paper award by the journal Naval Research Logistics in 2022. The nomination and decision was made based on nearly 200 papers published in the journal during the prior three years.

In the context of our results on modeling motivated from liver allocation, first we developed novel new methodologies that are applicable to estimate the entire waiting time distribution of a single server queue allowing for very general service time and organ arrival time distributions. Importantly, using our results we demonstrated that transplant centers which have relatively small transplant volume and transplant centers which list highly vulnerable patients should on the average have an increased share of allocated livers, when compared to transplant centers that are relatively larger in their transplant volume.
